VERY IMP: Don't fool your self with complexity of backtrack approach num 2. I spent hours to wrap my head around this.

For all those wondering how the complexity of approach 2 is 2^N, they are not fool. On one side, its taught that the way to calculate complexity of backtracking solution is to know what are our choices (k) on each recursion and how many times we recurse (N)..so if we have k choices each time and we recurse N times, complexity of backtrack solution is typically k^N...

In this case, folks could be genuinely confused, when the code looks exactly same, but complexity is 2^N and not N^N (as it seems like we have N choices at each step and we iterate N times in approach 2 code). However, that is *not true* bcz for such backtracking solutions, the choices should always remains N..however in this case, you can see that if we have taken an number, it is not available for reuse in next recursion..so the choices does not always remain N on each nested recursion but reduces...

This is where we have to do the hard thing, i.e. draw out the recursion tree manually and you will see the nested recursion happens 2^N times. And looking at solution 3, people know that we are kind of generating bitmask in which if we have N bits, the number of solutions becomes 2^N..so people often try to retrofit that complexity for approach 2 backtrack solution bcz deriving a mathematic formula is tricky in approach 2.

Thus, it would be helpful where we can clearly see that we are taking 2 choices. A loop doesn't help on that bcz it gives impression of N choices. That's why I have written backtrack code without loop that clearly shows 2 choices and helps derive 2^N complexity in backtrack solution. Checkout code here: https://leetcode.com/problems/subsets/solutions/3052149/simple-intuitive-solution-that-describes-the-backtrack-complexity-as-2-n/

In the problem, it is clearly mentioned that "The solution set must not contain duplicate subsets". But, below test cases are generating incorrect expected answer from OJ:

Expected Output: [[],[1],[2],[1,2],[2],[1,2],[2,2],[1,2,2]] (given by OJ)

As you can see above, the expected output from the OJ consists of duplicated subsets, which is contradicting with the problem constraints. Can anyone correct me, if I am mistaken here.
just read the constraints bro, you should be choose only unique elements.

There are 2 ways to solve 
1) Power Set Method
2)Recursion

My Recursion Solution :- https://leetcode.com/problems/subsets/submissions/974968426/

Subset is picking or discarding a element 
so you need to call 2 recursion call 1)pick  2)not pick

IN parameter list take array, index(point the element which is to be picked or discard), datastructure(to store 1 subset when base condition hits), ans list


In this approach we will be modifying our data structure in recursion calls and when the base condition hits(when u traversed the whole array) we will add a copy of our datastructure to ans list

Note :-Don't add the datastructure because it is pass by reference

If any doubt refer my attached solution

My advise would be draw recursion tree until you understand the code
Is there anyway we can do this question only using recursion without backtracking?
https://github.com/AnkushRawat10601/Leetcode/blob/main/78_subsets.cpp

This function uses a recursive helper function to generate all possible subsets of the input array. The helper function generates the subsets by considering each element in the array in turn and recursively generating the subsets both with and without the element.

The time complexity of this solution is O(2^n), where n is the number of elements in the array, because there are 2^n possible subsets of an array with n elements.

The space complexity of this solution is O(2^n), because the function stores all the subsets in the result array. The space complexity is not affected by the structure of the array, only by the number of elements.

There are 2 ways to solve 
1) Power Set Method
2)Recursion

title: Rank Scores
question_content:
Table: Scores

+-------------+---------+
| Column Name | Type    |
+-------------+---------+
| id          | int     |
| score       | decimal |
+-------------+---------+
id is the primary key (column with unique values) for this table.
Each row of this table contains the score of a game. Score is a floating point value with two decimal places.

 

Write a solution to find the rank of the scores. The ranking should be calculated according to the following rules:

  • The scores should be ranked from the highest to the lowest.
  • If there is a tie between two scores, both should have the same ranking.
  • After a tie, the next ranking number should be the next consecutive integer value. In other words, there should be no holes between ranks.

Return the result table ordered by score in descending order.

The result format is in the following example.

 

Example 1:

Input: 
Scores table:
+----+-------+
| id | score |
+----+-------+
| 1  | 3.50  |
| 2  | 3.65  |
| 3  | 4.00  |
| 4  | 3.85  |
| 5  | 4.00  |
| 6  | 3.65  |
+----+-------+
Output: 
+-------+------+
| score | rank |
+-------+------+
| 4.00  | 1    |
| 4.00  | 1    |
| 3.85  | 2    |
| 3.65  | 3    |
| 3.65  | 3    |
| 3.50  | 4    |
+-------+------+

solutions.title: simple-short-fast
solutions.content:
These are four different solutions.

---
**With Variables:** 841 ms

First one uses two variables, one for the current rank and one for the previous score.

    SELECT
      Score,
      @rank := @rank + (@prev <> (@prev := Score)) Rank
    FROM
      Scores,
      (SELECT @rank := 0, @prev := -1) init
    ORDER BY Score desc

---

**Always Count:** 1322 ms

This one counts, for each score, the number of distinct greater or equal scores.

    SELECT
      Score,
      (SELECT count(distinct Score) FROM Scores WHERE Score >= s.Score) Rank
    FROM Scores s
    ORDER BY Score desc

---

**Always Count, Pre-uniqued:** 795 ms

Same as the previous one, but faster because I have a subquery that "uniquifies" the scores first. Not entirely sure *why* it's faster, I'm guessing MySQL makes `tmp` a temporary table and uses it for every outer Score.

    SELECT
      Score,
      (SELECT count(*) FROM (SELECT distinct Score s FROM Scores) tmp WHERE s >= Score) Rank
    FROM Scores
    ORDER BY Score desc

---

**Filter/count Scores^2:** 1414 ms

Inspired by the attempt in wangkan2001's answer. Finally `Id` is good for something :-)

    SELECT s.Score, count(distinct t.score) Rank
    FROM Scores s JOIN Scores t ON s.Score <= t.score
    GROUP BY s.Id
    ORDER BY s.Score desc

    GROUP BY s.Id
    ORDER BY s.Score desc

solutions.title: mysql-two-simple-solutions-and-explanations-for-beginners
solutions.content:
# **1. MySQL Solution: (777ms)**
```
SELECT S.Score, COUNT(S2.Score) AS Rank FROM Scores S,
(SELECT DISTINCT Score FROM Scores) S2
WHERE S.Score<=S2.Score
GROUP BY S.Id 
ORDER BY S.Score DESC;
```
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/sophiesu0827/image_1576871668.png)




# **2. Optional MySQL solution using Variables: (397ms)**
```
SELECT Score, convert(Rank,SIGNED) AS Rank FROM
    (SELECT Score, @rank:=CASE WHEN Score=@previous THEN @rank ELSE @rank+1 END AS Rank, @previous:=Score FROM Scores,
        (SELECT @previous:=-1,@rank:=0) AS initial
    ORDER BY Score DESC) A;  
```
**Intuition:** 
First we sort the table by descending scores. We check each score to see if it is equal to or lower than the previous score. If equal, keep the same rank; If lower, increase the rank by 1.

**Yes! We've found that using Variables would save half of the running time.**
solutions.code:
```
SELECT S.Score, COUNT(S2.Score) AS Rank FROM Scores S,
(SELECT DISTINCT Score FROM Scores) S2
WHERE S.Score<=S2.Score
GROUP BY S.Id 
ORDER BY S.Score DESC;
```
```
SELECT Score, convert(Rank,SIGNED) AS Rank FROM
    (SELECT Score, @rank:=CASE WHEN Score=@previous THEN @rank ELSE @rank+1 END AS Rank, @previous:=Score FROM Scores,
        (SELECT @previous:=-1,@rank:=0) AS initial
    ORDER BY Score DESC) A;  
```

solutions.title: dense-rank-sql-server-604-ms
solutions.content:
Hello,

I am not sure why I have not come across a solution using DENSE_RANK() since it's made for exactly this purpose. Please do let me know if the goal of the question is to arrive at a solution without using DENSE_RANK().

NOTE : I am using MS SQL SERVER and not MySQL. It accepts my solution.

Here is my solution :

```
SELECT s.Score as Score,
DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY s.Score DESC) as Rank
FROM Scores s

```

it does exactly what the question asks us to do. If you want ranks with gaps, we can use RANK() instead of DENSE_RANK()
solutions.code:
```
SELECT s.Score as Score,
DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY s.Score DESC) as Rank
FROM Scores s

```

solutions.title: pandas-simple-2-step-approach-additional-knowledge-at-the-end
solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. Use the rank method with method='dense' to assign ranks to the scores in descending order while handling ties. Add a new column 'rank' to the scores DataFrame to store the ranks.
2. Sort the DataFrame by score in descending order. This can be achieved using the sort_values method.


# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    # Use the rank method to assign ranks to the scores in descending order with no gaps
    scores['rank'] = scores['score'].rank(method='dense', ascending=False)
    
    # Drop id column & Sort the DataFrame by score in descending order
    result_df = scores.drop('id',axis=1).sort_values(by='score', ascending=False)
    
    return result_df
```

# Additional Knowledge 🤩
The Approach is super simple if we know about the rank method and method = 'dense', but we should not stop here for this question let's explore and increase our knowledge.

what are other available options like dense? 🤔
In Pandas' rank method, there are several options available for the method parameter to handle ties when assigning ranks. Here are the available options:

**'average' (default):** This method assigns the average rank to tied elements. For example, if two elements tie for the second rank, they both get the rank of 2.5, and the next rank will be 4.

**'min':** This method assigns the minimum rank to tied elements. For example, if two elements tie for the second rank, they both get the rank of 2, and the next rank will be 4.

**'max':** This method assigns the maximum rank to tied elements. For example, if two elements tie for the second rank, they both get the rank of 3, and the next rank will be 4.

**'first':** This method assigns ranks in the order they appear in the input data, without using any average or other calculations for ties. For example, if two elements tie for the second rank, the first element gets the rank of 2, and the next rank will be 4.

**'dense':** This method assigns dense ranks to tied elements, meaning there are no gaps in the ranks. For example, if two elements tie for the second rank, they both get the rank of 2, and the next rank will be 3.

**'ordinal':** This method is similar to 'dense', but it considers the order of appearance in the data for assigning ranks to tied elements. For example, if two elements tie for the second rank, the first element gets the rank of 2, and the next rank will be 3.

These methods allow you to choose how ties in the data should be handled while assigning ranks. You can select the appropriate method based on your specific requirements. By default, 'average' is used when the method parameter is not provided.

## Please upvote the solution which gives me motivation to share high quality solutions like this. Thank You.
solutions.code:
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    # Use the rank method to assign ranks to the scores in descending order with no gaps
    scores['rank'] = scores['score'].rank(method='dense', ascending=False)
    
    # Drop id column & Sort the DataFrame by score in descending order
    result_df = scores.drop('id',axis=1).sort_values(by='score', ascending=False)
    
    return result_df
```

solutions.title: mysql-solution
solutions.content:
# Solution
```
SELECT score, dense_rank() OVER(ORDER BY score DESC) as "rank"
FROM Scores
```
The **DENSE_RANK()** is a window function that assigns a rank to each row within a partition of a result set. Unlike the **RANK()** function, the **DENSE_RANK()** function returns consecutive rank values. Rows in each partition receive the same ranks if they have the same values.
If you find this **solution** and **explanation** helpful, please **upvote** it for others people.
solutions.code:
```
SELECT score, dense_rank() OVER(ORDER BY score DESC) as "rank"
FROM Scores
```

solutions.title: accepted-solution-using-innerjoin-and-groupby
solutions.content:
SELECT Scores.Score, COUNT(Ranking.Score) AS RANK
      FROM Scores
         , (
           SELECT DISTINCT Score
             FROM Scores
           ) Ranking
     WHERE Scores.Score <= Ranking.Score
     GROUP BY Scores.Id, Scores.Score
     ORDER BY Scores.Score DESC;

solutions.title: accepted-solution-with-subqueries-and-group-by
solutions.content:
# Solution with sub-queries

We just get the rows the distinct rows that are <= that each score, count them and wrap them in an external SELECT for formatting. 

    SELECT Scores.Score, Q3.Rank
    FROM(
        SELECT Q1.Score as Score, COUNT(Q1.Score) as Rank
        FROM 
            (SELECT DISTINCT Score from Scores) as Q1,
            (SELECT DISTINCT Score from Scores) as Q2
        WHERE Q1.Score <= Q2.Score
        GROUP BY Q1.Score
        ) as Q3, Scores
    WHERE Q3.Score = Scores.Score
    ORDER BY Scores.Score DESC
solutions.code:
# Solution with sub-queries

We just get the rows the distinct rows that are <= that each score, count them and wrap them in an external SELECT for formatting. 

    SELECT Scores.Score, Q3.Rank
    FROM(
        SELECT Q1.Score as Score, COUNT(Q1.Score) as Rank
        FROM 
            (SELECT DISTINCT Score from Scores) as Q1,
            (SELECT DISTINCT Score from Scores) as Q2
        WHERE Q1.Score <= Q2.Score
        GROUP BY Q1.Score
        ) as Q3, Scores
    WHERE Q3.Score = Scores.Score
    ORDER BY Scores.Score DESC

solutions.title: fast-windows-vs-windowless-function-examples
solutions.content:
Generally, interviewers want you to use a Windows Function to solve a problem like this.  

However, you might have an interviewer who specifically says, don't use a Windows Function, so it's good to know both ways.

Has anyone every asked you to answer a question like this without a subquery?

Thanks!

[@easyCodingSolutions](https://youtu.be/K3KFG8Hpb2M)

https://youtu.be/K3KFG8Hpb2M

With Windows Function:

```
# Using DENSE_RANK - generally what interviewers want
SELECT
    score

solutions.title: concise-solution-with-sql-ranking
solutions.content:
There are many ways we can calculate the rank of each score, the easiest is to use a built in method named `DENSE_RANK()`. 

```
SELECT 
    score, 
    DENSE_RANK() OVER(ORDER BY score desc) AS `rank` 
FROM scores
ORDER BY `rank`
```

Two things to take in consideration here:

1. There is another method called `RANK()` which will give different result for the same query. If you don't understand their difference, I would suggest you to try this with `RANK()` and see the difference in results, it will help you.
2. In the 3rd line you have to put the alias `rank` inside `` or `""`, otherwise mysql will give error. This is because `rank` is a syntax used by mysql itself so you have to tell the db engine explicitely that it's not the build in method, it's a string.
solutions.code:
```
SELECT 
    score, 
    DENSE_RANK() OVER(ORDER BY score desc) AS `rank` 
FROM scores
ORDER BY `rank`
```

solutions.content:
# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:

    #Sorting the table in descending Order
    scores=scores.sort_values(by=['score'],ascending=False)

    #Using 'rank' to rank the rows in descending method
    #'dense' method gives ranks continuous without any gap. 
    scores['rank']=(scores['score'].rank(method='dense',ascending=False))

    return scores[['score','rank']]
```

solutions.title: 178-solution-with-step-by-step-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
To rank the scores, we can use a window function DENSE_RANK() in SQL. The DENSE_RANK() function assigns ranks to rows within the partition of a result set. If two or more rows have the same value, they receive the same rank, and the next rank is assigned to the next row.

Here's the SQL query to rank the scores:
```
SELECT score, DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) as `rank`
FROM Scores
ORDER BY score DESC;
```
This query selects the score column and applies the DENSE_RANK() function to it, which will generate the ranking. We order the result set by the score in descending order, which means the highest score will have the rank 1.

The output of the query for the given input in the problem statement will be:

```
+-------+------+
| score | rank |
+-------+------+
| 4.00  | 1    |
| 4.00  | 1    |
| 3.85  | 2    |
| 3.65  | 3    |
| 3.65  | 3    |
| 3.50  | 4    |
+-------+------+

```
Second example solution:

```
SELECT score, DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) as 'rank'
FROM Scores;
```
# Complexity
- Time complexity:

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

FROM Scores
ORDER BY score DESC;

```

solutions.title: two-mysql-solutions-simple-dense-rank-and-complex-row-number
solutions.content:
1. Simple Method (which a lot of people have used)

```
SELECT score, DENSE_RANK() over (ORDER BY score DESC) AS 'rank'
FROM Scores
```

2. Complex Method (if dense_rank did not exist) - Faster than 88.95% of MySQL submissions

```
WITH s1 AS (SELECT score, 
            ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS 'rank'
FROM Scores
GROUP BY score) # First create a table with unique row numbers for each distinct score

SELECT s1.score, s1.rank
FROM s1
RIGHT JOIN Scores AS s2  
USING (score) # join two tables using score as the foreign key
ORDER BY score DESC
```

solutions.title: row-number-vs-rank-vs-dense-rank
solutions.content:
This question is a great place to learn these 3 functions. The best way for you to understand these 3 functions is to simply run the below code for them and see why and what they produce as output. The correct answer is given by DENSE_RANK() but a beginner will always get confused on why and when to use DENSE_RANK() or RANK() or ROW_NUMBER()

**ROW_NUMBER()** is like a basic counting function, where it will give continous ranks like 1-2-3-4-5-6 and does not care if the values are same or not. So lets suppose we have three people with marks as 100, 100 and 99. ROW_NUMBER() will give rank 1 to person with 100/100 marks and then give rank 2 to person with 100/100 marks and then give rank 3 to person with 99 marks.

* Rank 1 --- 100/100 marks Person A
* Rank 2 --- 100/100 marks Person B
* Rank 3 --- 99/100 marks Person C

```
SELECT 
    score AS "score",
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
        ORDER BY score DESC
    ) AS "rank"
FROM
    Scores
;
```

**RANK()** is the very close to the correct answer for this question but RANK() leaves hole when it operates. So lets suppose we have three people with marks as 100, 100 and 99. RANK() will give rank 1 to person with 100/100 marks and then give rank 1 to person with 100/100 marks but in the end it will give rank 3 to person with 99 marks.

* Rank 1 --- 100/100 marks Person A
* Rank 1 --- 100/100 marks Person B
* Rank 3 ---  99/100 marks Person C

```
SELECT 
    score AS "score",
    RANK() OVER (
        ORDER BY score DESC
    ) AS "rank"
FROM
    Scores
;
```

**DENSE_RANK()** is the perfect function as per our given requirments. So lets suppose we have three people with marks as 100, 100 and 99. DENSE_RANK() will give rank 1 to person with 100/100 marks and then give rank 1 to person with 100/100 marks but in the end it will give rank 2 to person with 99 marks.

* Rank 1 --- 100/100 marks Person A
* Rank 1 --- 100/100 marks Person B
* Rank 2 ---  99/100 marks Person C
```
SELECT 
    score AS "score",
    DENSE_RANK() OVER (
        ORDER BY score DESC
    ) AS "rank"
FROM
    Scores
;
```

    score AS "score",
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
        ORDER BY score DESC
    ) AS "rank"
FROM
    Scores
;
```
```
SELECT 
    score AS "score",
    RANK() OVER (
        ORDER BY score DESC
    ) AS "rank"
FROM
    Scores
;
```
```
SELECT 
    score AS "score",
    DENSE_RANK() OVER (
        ORDER BY score DESC
    ) AS "rank"
FROM
    Scores
;
```

solutions.title: 3-easiest-ways
solutions.content:
Classic way
```
SELECT s.score
     , DENSE_RANK() OVER(ORDER BY score DESC) AS rank
  FROM scores s
 ORDER BY s.score DESC
```
One stupid way. Use on the interview is your interviewer doesn't know or hates window functions
```
SELECT t.score
     , (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT s.score)  FROM scores s WHERE s.score >=t.score)  AS rank 
  FROM scores t
 ORDER BY t.score DESC
```

3th way (MySQL):
```
SELECT s1.score
, 1+COUNT(DISTINCT CASE WHEN s2.score>s1.score AND s1.id!=s2.id THEN s2.score ELSE NULL END) AS "rank"
FROM scores s1
CROSS JOIN
scores s2
GROUP BY s1.id
, s1.score
ORDER BY 2 ASC
```

solutions.title: easy-using-methods-to-rank-rows-in-sql
solutions.content:
```
SELECT score, dense_rank() over (order by score desc) as 'Rank'
FROM scores
```



Please note that the description says "If there is a tie between two scores, both should have the same ranking. Note that after a tie, the next ranking number should be the next consecutive integer value" 

That's why you need to use **DENSE_RANK** instead of rank or row_number. 

See the functions for other rank methods:
-- row_number() : "Returns a unique number for each row" IN CASE OF A TIE: with rankings arbitrarily assigned 
-- rank() "Returns the same ranking" IN CASE OF A TIE: gaps* in the rankings
-- dense_rank() "Returns the same ranking" IN CASE OF A TIE: no gaps in the rankings
solutions.code:
```
SELECT score, dense_rank() over (order by score desc) as 'Rank'
FROM scores
```

solutions.title: faster-than-99
solutions.content:
Subquery the grouped score with a rank so that you can duplicate the rows.
```
SELECT Scores.score, x.rank
FROM Scores
INNER JOIN (
    SELECT score, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) as "rank"
    FROM Scores
    GROUP BY score
) x ON x.score = Scores.score
ORDER BY x.rank
```

solutions.title: mysql-solution-works-on-leetcode-s-version-5-7
solutions.content:
Generating `row_number` would have been a lot easier with version 8 with `ROW_NUMBER() OVER()`. Unfornately LeetCode has an older version of MySQL that does not have this feature.
```SQL
SELECT s.Score, r.Rank
FROM (
    --  Subquery 2: Generate row_number
    SELECT Score, (@row_number:=@row_number + 1) AS `Rank`
    FROM (
        -- Subquery 1: Generate ranked, unique scores
        SELECT Score
        FROM Scores
        GROUP BY Score
        ORDER BY Score DESC
    ) AS s, (SELECT @row_number:=0) AS dummie
) AS r
RIGHT JOIN Scores AS s
    ON s.Score = r.Score
ORDER BY r.Rank;
```
solutions.code:

FROM (

    SELECT Score, (@row_number:=@row_number + 1) AS `Rank`
    FROM (
        -- Subquery 1: Generate ranked, unique scores
        SELECT Score
        FROM Scores
        GROUP BY Score
        ORDER BY Score DESC
    ) AS s, (SELECT @row_number:=0) AS dummie
) AS r
RIGHT JOIN Scores AS s
    ON s.Score = r.Score
ORDER BY r.Rank;
```

solutions.title: simple-solution-using-correlated-subquery
solutions.content:
```
select score,
(select count(s2.score) from (select distinct score from scores) s2 
where s2.score >= s1.score) as "RANK"
from scores s1 
ORDER BY score DESC;
```

Approach : Rank will be decided based on unique scores. We want rank of all the scores. So the idea is to loop for all distinct scores and find the count of scores(s2) greater than or equal to current distinct score (s1) and store it as rank and display it in descending order.
solutions.code:
```
select score,
(select count(s2.score) from (select distinct score from scores) s2 
where s2.score >= s1.score) as "RANK"
from scores s1 
ORDER BY score DESC;
```

solutions.title: pandas-3-lines-sort-dense-rank
solutions.content:
# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    df = scores.sort_values(by='score', ascending=False)
    # assign lowest rank to highest value
    # `method='dense'` assigns same rank to equal values without skipping ranks
    df['rank'] = df['score'].rank(method='dense', ascending=False) 
    return df[['score','rank']]

```
solutions.code:
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    df = scores.sort_values(by='score', ascending=False)
    # assign lowest rank to highest value
    # `method='dense'` assigns same rank to equal values without skipping ranks
    df['rank'] = df['score'].rank(method='dense', ascending=False) 
    return df[['score','rank']]

```

solutions.title: mysql-server-solution-for-rank-scores-problem
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The goal of this SQL query is to retrieve the scores from the Scores table along with their corresponding rank, where the rank is determined by the score in descending order.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. Use the dense_rank() function to assign a rank to each score in the Scores table, ordered by score in descending order.
2. Select the Score column and the rank assigned by the dense_rank() function.
3. The result set will contain one row for each score in the Scores table, with the score and its corresponding rank.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
 The time complexity of this query depends on the size of the Scores table and the efficiency of the database engine's query optimizer. In general, the time complexity of a query with an ORDER BY clause is O(n * log n), where n is the number of rows in the table. However, the dense_rank() function may help to optimize the query execution plan and reduce the actual time complexity.

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The space complexity of this query depends on the size of the result set and the size of the columns being selected. In this case, the result set will have at most as many rows as the Scores table, and each row will have two columns (Score and Rank). Therefore, the space complexity is O(n), where n is the number of rows in the Scores table.


# Code
```
/* Write your T-SQL query statement below */
select Score, dense_rank() over(order by Score desc) as Rank from Scores;
```

solutions.title: mysql-dense-rank-vs-rank
solutions.content:
# Using **DENSE_RANK()**
```
SELECT score, DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score desc) as 'rank'
FROM Scores
ORDER BY score desc
```

# Using **RANK()**
Rank() not assigning rank in a consecutive order, it is assigning by a rank of row within same categories/ score in this case.


```
SELECT score, RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score desc) as 'rank'
FROM Scores
ORDER BY score desc
```
The following are the differences between using **DENSE_RANK()** and **RANK()**:

FROM Scores
ORDER BY score desc
```

FROM Scores
ORDER BY score desc
```

solutions.title: faster-than-99-95-solution-using-mysql-s-built-in-windowing-s-dense-rank
solutions.content:
Runtime: 208 ms, faster than 99.95% of MySQL online submissions for Rank Scores.
Memory Usage: 0B, less than 100.00% of MySQL online submissions for Rank Scores.

The simplest solution is to use built-in Windowing with a [`DENSE_RANK` function](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/window-function-descriptions.html#function_dense-rank), which by design gives exactly what we need.

To learn more, please see [MySQL documentation and examples on Windowing](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/window-functions-usage.html). Windowing concept is very powerful and is definitely the fastest way to calculate ranks, sums, averages, counts on "buckets" of data, where by the bucket I understand a group of data (groupped by a certain characteristic, like date, category or a given value type). Whereas Windowing is a bit harder to master, it's definitely useful when creating reports.

```sql
# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT
    s.score,
    DENSE_RANK() OVER (
        ORDER BY s.score DESC
    ) 'rank'
FROM Scores s;
```

solutions.title: simple-and-easy-to-understand
solutions.content:
```
SELECT Scores.Score ,COUNT(DISTINCT greater.Score)+1 AS Rank
FROM Scores
LEFT JOIN Scores greater ON greater.Score>Scores.Score
GROUP BY Scores.Id
ORDER BY Rank
```

Notice that 'rank of a score' = '#unique scores' + 1. For example, rank(4.0) = 0(no unique score greater than 4.0) + 1 = 1. 
We want to count unique score here because we want dense rank, which means all scores with the same value will be calculated as one rank (say two 4.0 won't let 3.85 be rank3)。
In the sql，we left join the original table with itself and calculate distinct count of scores greater than the current value. And the rank of current value = this count+1
solutions.code:
```
SELECT Scores.Score ,COUNT(DISTINCT greater.Score)+1 AS Rank
FROM Scores
LEFT JOIN Scores greater ON greater.Score>Scores.Score
GROUP BY Scores.Id
ORDER BY Rank
```

    SELECT Score, CASE

        THEN @countRank 
        ELSE @countRank := @countRank + 1 
        END AS Rank, @preScore := Score AS preScore
    FROM Scores AS s, (SELECT @countRank := 0, @preScore := NULL) AS p
    ORDER BY Score DESC) AS sr;

solutions.title: 184ms-solution-beats-100-submission-easy-to-understand
solutions.content:
Runtime 184ms

First, create a table with distinct score and generate new rank id from 1 to 4.
Second, left join with Scores table on score, keep score and rank id, then order by rank.

```
Select Scores.score as Score, rank.rankid as Rank
from
scores left join
(select @rowid := @rowid + 1 as rankid, temp1.score
from 
    (select distinct score from scores order by score desc) as temp1, 
    (select @rowid:=0) as temp2) as rank
on Scores.score = rank.score
order by Rank
```

solutions.title: pandas-2-easy-and-different-ways-to-solve
solutions.content:
**🔼 IF YOU FIND THIS POST HELPFUL PLEASE UPVOTE 👍**

**Method 1:**
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    df = scores.sort_values(by='score', ascending=False)
    
    rank = []
    max_score = 1e9
    curr_rank = 0
    
    for idx, row in df.iterrows():
        if row.score == max_score:
            rank.append(curr_rank)
        else:
            max_score = row.score
            curr_rank += 1
            rank.append(curr_rank)
            
    df['rank'] = rank
    
    return df[['score', 'rank']]
```

**Method 2:**
```
import pandas as pd

def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    scores['rank'] = scores['score'].rank(method='dense', ascending=False)
    
    return scores[['score', 'rank']].sort_values(by='score', ascending=False)
```

solutions.title: one-liner-solution-with-explanation
solutions.content:
## ***Please Upvote my solution, if you find it helpful ;)***

# Intuition
The intuition behind the solution is to use the **dense_rank()** function to assign ranks to the scores in descending order, ensuring that higher scores receive lower ranks.


# Approach
To solve the problem, we need to rank the scores in descending order and assign a rank to each score. Here's how your SQL query accomplishes this:

1. The SELECT statement is used to select the "Score" column from the "Scores" table. This retrieves all the scores from the table.

1. The **DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY Score DESC)** function is used to calculate the rank of each score. The DENSE_RANK() function assigns the same rank to scores with the same value, and the ranks are determined based on the score values. The ORDER BY Score DESC part ensures that the scores are sorted in descending order before assigning the ranks.

1. The result of the query includes both the "Score" and "Rank" columns. This means that for each score, you will see its corresponding rank in the output.

1. The query handles the ranking and ordering of the scores for us, so we don't need to manually implement any logic to determine the ranks. By using the **DENSE_RANK()** function, the query efficiently assigns ranks to the scores in descending order.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
The time complexity of this approach is dependent on the number of scores in the Scores table and the efficiency of the DENSE_RANK() function. The time complexity is typically $$O(n log n)$$ or better, as it involves sorting the scores.

- Space complexity:
The space complexity is determined by the size of the input data (the Scores table) and the storage required for the result set. In this case, the space complexity is $$O(n)$$, where n is the number of scores in the table.


# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below

SELECT Score, DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY Score DESC) AS Rank FROM Scores;

```

solutions.title: ms-sql
solutions.content:
#### Question
````
SQL Schema
Table: Scores

+-------------+---------+
| Column Name | Type    |
+-------------+---------+
| Id          | int     |
| Score       | decimal |
+-------------+---------+
Id is the primary key for this table.
Each row of this table contains the score of a game. Score is a floating point value with two decimal places.
 

Write an SQL query to rank the scores. The ranking should be calculated according to the following rules:

The scores should be ranked from the highest to the lowest.
If there is a tie between two scores, both should have the same ranking.
After a tie, the next ranking number should be the next consecutive integer value. In other words, there should be no holes between ranks.
Return the result table ordered by score in descending order.

The query result format is in the following example.

 

Example 1:

Input: 
Scores table:
+----+-------+
| Id | Score |
+----+-------+
| 1  | 3.50  |
| 2  | 3.65  |
| 3  | 4.00  |
| 4  | 3.85  |
| 5  | 4.00  |
| 6  | 3.65  |
+----+-------+
Output: 
+-------+------+
| Score | Rank |
+-------+------+
| 4.00  | 1    |
| 4.00  | 1    |
| 3.85  | 2    |
| 3.65  | 3    |
| 3.65  | 3    |
| 3.50  | 4    |
+-------+------+
````
#### Answer
```
select Score, dense_rank() over (order by Score desc) as Rank from Scores
order by Score desc

solutions.title: easy-solution-only-use-rank-faster-than-96-memory-less-than-100
solutions.content:
The difference in using between **dense_rank** or **rank** is that, the former one would consider the tied numbers only will take one position in the rank, while the later one would consider the tied numbers will take consecutive potitions in the rank, which will leave holes in the rank.

Easy to understood coding part:

```
select score, dense_rank() over(order by score desc) as Rank
from scores
order by 1 desc
```
This is the reference link for SQL RANK functions, very helpful:
https://www.sqlshack.com/overview-of-sql-rank-functions/
solutions.code:
```
select score, dense_rank() over(order by score desc) as Rank
from scores
order by 1 desc
```

solutions.title: easy-to-understand-mysql-with-explanation
solutions.content:
First, we need 2 tables: The original table and another table where we only have distinct scores
Table A: `SELECT A.id, A.score FROM Scores A`
Table B: `SELECT DISTINCT(score) as score FROM Scores B`

Then we JOIN both the tables where the scores from Table A <= Table B:
```
SELECT A.id, A.score, B.score
FROM Scores A JOIN (SELECT DISTINCT(score) as score FROM Scores) B ON A.score<=B.score
ORDER BY A.id, A.score DESC, B.score ASC
```
The trick here is where A.score <= B.score.

Now, we GROUP BY A.id, COUNT B.score and lastly order A.score in descending order.
```
SELECT A.score as Score, COUNT(B.score) as 'Rank'
FROM Scores A JOIN (SELECT DISTINCT(score) as score FROM Scores) B ON A.score<=B.score
GROUP BY A.id
ORDER BY A.score DESC
```
solutions.code:
```
SELECT A.id, A.score, B.score
FROM Scores A JOIN (SELECT DISTINCT(score) as score FROM Scores) B ON A.score<=B.score
ORDER BY A.id, A.score DESC, B.score ASC
```
```
SELECT A.score as Score, COUNT(B.score) as 'Rank'
FROM Scores A JOIN (SELECT DISTINCT(score) as score FROM Scores) B ON A.score<=B.score
GROUP BY A.id
ORDER BY A.score DESC
```

solutions.title: simple-approach
solutions.content:
The following is an accepted and simple solution to the problem: 

1. Get a table of distinct scores ordered from highest to lowest. 
2. Add a serial colum to the table from step 1, the values of the new column are incremented starting from zero and going down.
3. Merge the table from step 2 with the Scores table.

Execution time < 200 ms. 

```
SELECT      Scores.Score, Rank 
FROM        Scores 
LEFT JOIN   (                                       -- Last: Join with original scores table on the score value.
                SELECT  Score, @a:=@a+1 Rank        -- Second: Add column of serial values starting from 1 to the ordered scores.
                FROM    (                           -- First: Get table of distinct scores ordered from highest to lowers.
                            SELECT DISTINCT Score
                            FROM Scores
                            ORDER BY Score DESC
                        ) AS orderedScores, (SELECT @a:= 0) AS a
            ) AS rankedScores ON (rankedScores.Score = Scores.Score)
ORDER BY    Scores.Score DESC
```
solutions.code:
```
SELECT      Scores.Score, Rank 
FROM        Scores 
LEFT JOIN   (                                       -- Last: Join with original scores table on the score value.
                SELECT  Score, @a:=@a+1 Rank        -- Second: Add column of serial values starting from 1 to the ordered scores.
                FROM    (                           -- First: Get table of distinct scores ordered from highest to lowers.
                            SELECT DISTINCT Score
                            FROM Scores
                            ORDER BY Score DESC
                        ) AS orderedScores, (SELECT @a:= 0) AS a
            ) AS rankedScores ON (rankedScores.Score = Scores.Score)
ORDER BY    Scores.Score DESC
```

solutions.title: pandas-dense-rank
solutions.content:
```
import pandas as pd


def order_scores(scores: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    scores['rank'] = (
        scores
        .score
        .rank(method='dense', ascending=False)
        .astype(int)
    )

    scores.sort_values('score', inplace=True, ascending=False)

    return scores[['score', 'rank']]
```

import pandas as pd

    scores['rank'] = (

        .rank(method='dense', ascending=False)
        .astype(int)
    )

    return scores[['score', 'rank']]
```

solutions.title: using-different-types-of-window-functions
solutions.content:
# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below

    SELECT score,
    DENSE_RANK() OVER(ORDER BY score DESC) AS 'rank'
    FROM Scores
```
# DENSE_RANK()
DENSE_RANK() is a window function in SQL that is used to calculate the rank of each row within a result set. It works similarly to the RANK() function, but unlike RANK(), DENSE_RANK() doesn't leave gaps between the ranks when there are ties.

Here's an example to illustrate the difference between RANK() and DENSE_RANK(). Suppose we have the following table:

```
+------+-------+
| id   | score |
+------+-------+
| 1    | 90    |
| 2    | 85    |
| 3    | 80    |
| 4    | 80    |
| 5    | 75    |
+------+-------+
```
If we use RANK() to calculate the ranks of the scores, we get the following:

```
SELECT score, RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS 'rank' FROM Scores;
```

```
+-------+------+
| score | rank |
+-------+------+
| 90    | 1    |
| 85    | 2    |
| 80    | 3    |
| 80    | 3    |
| 75    | 5    |
+-------+------+
```
As you can see, there is a gap between ranks 2 and 3 because there is a tie between scores 80 and 80.

If we use DENSE_RANK() instead, we get the following:


```
SELECT score, DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS 'rank' FROM Scores;
```

```
+-------+------+
| score | rank |
+-------+------+
| 90    | 1    |
| 85    | 2    |
| 80    | 3    |
| 80    | 3    |
| 75    | 4    |
+-------+------+
```
As you can see, DENSE_RANK() assigns the same rank to the tied scores (80 and 80) and doesn't leave any gaps between ranks.

In summary, DENSE_RANK() is a window function that calculates the rank of each row in a result set, but doesn't leave gaps between the ranks when there are ties.

solutions.title: mysql-ranking-functions-implementation-and-explanation
solutions.content:
### Ranking functions in MySQL

```
SELECT score, dense_rank() OVER (
                ORDER BY score DESC
            ) AS 'rank'
FROM Scores;
```

***REFERENCE***
[https://www.sqlshack.com/overview-of-sql-rank-functions/](http://)
***about ROWNUMBER(), RANK(), denserank(), NTILE(N)

We use DENSERANK() function to specify a unique rank number within the partition as per the specified column value. It is similar to the Rank function with a small difference.

In the SQL RANK function DENSERANK(), if we have duplicate values, SQL assigns different ranks to those rows as well. Ideally, we should get the same rank for duplicate or similar values.

Let’s execute the following query with the DENSERANK() function.
```
SELECT Studentname, 
       Subject, 
       Marks, 
       DENSERANK() OVER(ORDER BY Marks DESC) Rank
FROM ExamResult
ORDER BY Rank;
```
In the output, you can see we have the same rank for both Lily and Isabella who scored 70 marks.***

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/8a8c58ed-64ee-40a5-b59a-efd8a59576d6_1666098734.50629.png)
solutions.code:
```
SELECT score, dense_rank() OVER (
                ORDER BY score DESC
            ) AS 'rank'
FROM Scores;
```
```
SELECT Studentname, 
       Subject, 
       Marks, 
       DENSERANK() OVER(ORDER BY Marks DESC) Rank
FROM ExamResult
ORDER BY Rank;
```

group by s1.Id

; 

Please make sure using where **s2**.Score >= **s1**.Score. Think in this way: Use table s2 to store the cumulative count(), and rank means "how many other scores greater than or equal to itself". For example, rank = 1 means there are only 1 another score >= itself, while rank = 6 means there are other 6 scores >= itself. Hope this makes sense.

If I can do this, this problem would be very easy.

Just create an intermediate table which contains  distinct, sorted score and its ranking, then join it with original table.

Here is the code:

set @rank:=0;

select myScore.Score, myRank.Rank

from (select Score from Scores order by Score desc) as myScore, (select Score, @rank:=@rank+1 as Rank from Scores group by Score order by Score desc) as myRank

where myScore.Score = myRank.Score

**Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) `Rank`
FROM Scores

**Not Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT b.Score)+1 FROM Scores b WHERE b.Score > Scores.Score) as `Rank`
FROM Scores
Order by 1 desc;

so i looked up online, seems like mysql does have dense_rank() clause, but there are some popel say it doesn't. Mysql workbench have this clause![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/victorlifan/image_1581621601.png).
i am assuming leetcode need to update their mysql platform perhaps?
`select Score, dense_rank() over(order by Score desc) as \'Rank\' from Scores`
`select s1.score ,(select count(distinct score) from scores s2 where s2.score>=s1.score) as "rank" \n from scores s1 order by s1.score desc`

Does anyone know why I can't initialize variable like this "set @rank:=0"?

If I can do this, this problem would be very easy.

Just create an intermediate table which contains  distinct, sorted score and its ranking, then join it with original table.

Here is the code:

set @rank:=0;

select myScore.Score, myRank.Rank

from (select Score from Scores order by Score desc) as myScore, (select Score, @rank:=@rank+1 as Rank from Scores group by Score order by Score desc) as myRank

where myScore.Score = myRank.Score

**Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) `Rank`
FROM Scores

**Not Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT b.Score)+1 FROM Scores b WHERE b.Score > Scores.Score) as `Rank`
FROM Scores
Order by 1 desc;

Subquery shows number of score that's larger than the score in the original table. So the max one has 0 score larger than itself. '+1' to get the rank as '1'. This is similar to question 185:)
Rank is a keyword so use  \'Rank\' with single quotes while giving column name

[@ishtiaq755](/ishtiaq755) That\'s not what OP is talking about. They are talking about labeling your column name as "rank". If you don\'t use quotations then it will throw a runtime error for the reason OP listed.
omg, thank you so much
we need to use DENSE_RANK here , because only RANK keyword wont give you consecutive ranking numbers.
Thanks
Thanks mate

1)
select score,  dense_rank()over( order by score desc) rank from scores

2)
select a.score, count(b.score) as rank
from scores a
 join
(
select distinct score
from scores
) b
on a.score <= b.score
group by a.id, a.score
order by a.score desc

***Upvote if liked it***
Thank you so much for ruining the problem in the discussion. We all appreciate it.

**# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT s.Score , COUNT(t.Score) AS 'Rank' FROM
(SELECT DISTINCT Score FROM Scores) AS t ,  Scores AS s
WHERE s.Score <= t.Score
GROUP BY s.id,s.Score
ORDER BY s.Score DESC;**

[@KrishnaSeven](/KrishnaSeven) you basically have to create two copies of the table scores, one is the normal one and the other one with just the distinct scores which will be helpful to rank the scores. for each current score check with the other copy table you created . The number of distinct scores that are more than the current score will be its rank logically. After that just group it by id and score then order it by the scores to get the desired query output.
can you please explain?

Here is the right MySQL code: 
'''
SELECT 
    score, 
    DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS  'rank'
FROM Scores
ORDER BY score DESC
'''

I can only run with rank surrounded by single quotation. But Alias does not require single quotation, right? Why can't I run with AS rank?

you should write like this (DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC)) as 'Rank'
here we have multiple words so mysql cannot understand for which element it should use name so by default it assumes (order by score desc) as rank
Because in MySQL the word RANK is a reserved word.

# Write your MySQL query statement below
select s1.Score, count(distinct s2.Score) as Rank from Scores s1, Scores s2 
where s2.Score >= s1.Score
group by s1.Id
order by Rank
; 

Please make sure using where **s2**.Score >= **s1**.Score. Think in this way: Use table s2 to store the cumulative count(), and rank means "how many other scores greater than or equal to itself". For example, rank = 1 means there are only 1 another score >= itself, while rank = 6 means there are other 6 scores >= itself. Hope this makes sense.

**# Write your MySQL query statement below
SELECT s.Score , COUNT(t.Score) AS 'Rank' FROM
(SELECT DISTINCT Score FROM Scores) AS t ,  Scores AS s
WHERE s.Score <= t.Score
GROUP BY s.id,s.Score
ORDER BY s.Score DESC;**

[@KrishnaSeven](/KrishnaSeven) you basically have to create two copies of the table scores, one is the normal one and the other one with just the distinct scores which will be helpful to rank the scores. for each current score check with the other copy table you created . The number of distinct scores that are more than the current score will be its rank logically. After that just group it by id and score then order it by the scores to get the desired query output.
can you please explain?

Here is the right MySQL code: 
'''
SELECT 
    score, 
    DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS  'rank'
FROM Scores
ORDER BY score DESC
'''

I can only run with rank surrounded by single quotation. But Alias does not require single quotation, right? Why can't I run with AS rank?

you should write like this (DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC)) as 'Rank'
here we have multiple words so mysql cannot understand for which element it should use name so by default it assumes (order by score desc) as rank
Because in MySQL the word RANK is a reserved word.

# Write your MySQL query statement below
select s1.Score, count(distinct s2.Score) as Rank from Scores s1, Scores s2 
where s2.Score >= s1.Score
group by s1.Id
order by Rank
; 

Please make sure using where **s2**.Score >= **s1**.Score. Think in this way: Use table s2 to store the cumulative count(), and rank means "how many other scores greater than or equal to itself". For example, rank = 1 means there are only 1 another score >= itself, while rank = 6 means there are other 6 scores >= itself. Hope this makes sense.

Does anyone know why I can't initialize variable like this "set @rank:=0"?

If I can do this, this problem would be very easy.

Just create an intermediate table which contains  distinct, sorted score and its ranking, then join it with original table.

Here is the code:

set @rank:=0;

select myScore.Score, myRank.Rank

from (select Score from Scores order by Score desc) as myScore, (select Score, @rank:=@rank+1 as Rank from Scores group by Score order by Score desc) as myRank

where myScore.Score = myRank.Score

**Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) `Rank`
FROM Scores

**Not Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT b.Score)+1 FROM Scores b WHERE b.Score > Scores.Score) as `Rank`
FROM Scores
Order by 1 desc;

Subquery shows number of score that's larger than the score in the original table. So the max one has 0 score larger than itself. '+1' to get the rank as '1'. This is similar to question 185:)

can you please explain?

Here is the right MySQL code: 
'''
SELECT 
    score, 
    DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) AS  'rank'
FROM Scores
ORDER BY score DESC
'''

I can only run with rank surrounded by single quotation. But Alias does not require single quotation, right? Why can't I run with AS rank?

you should write like this (DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC)) as 'Rank'
here we have multiple words so mysql cannot understand for which element it should use name so by default it assumes (order by score desc) as rank
Because in MySQL the word RANK is a reserved word.

# Write your MySQL query statement below
select s1.Score, count(distinct s2.Score) as Rank from Scores s1, Scores s2 
where s2.Score >= s1.Score
group by s1.Id
order by Rank
; 

Please make sure using where **s2**.Score >= **s1**.Score. Think in this way: Use table s2 to store the cumulative count(), and rank means "how many other scores greater than or equal to itself". For example, rank = 1 means there are only 1 another score >= itself, while rank = 6 means there are other 6 scores >= itself. Hope this makes sense.

i got an error when i used mysql with this query:
'''SELECT Score,
DENSE_RANK()OVER(ORDER BY Score DESC) AS Rank
FROM Scores;'''
so i looked up online, seems like mysql does have dense_rank() clause, but there are some popel say it doesn't. Mysql workbench have this clause![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/victorlifan/image_1581621601.png).
i am assuming leetcode need to update their mysql platform perhaps?
`select Score, dense_rank() over(order by Score desc) as \'Rank\' from Scores`
`select s1.score ,(select count(distinct score) from scores s2 where s2.score>=s1.score) as "rank" \n from scores s1 order by s1.score desc`

Does anyone know why I can't initialize variable like this "set @rank:=0"?

If I can do this, this problem would be very easy.

Just create an intermediate table which contains  distinct, sorted score and its ranking, then join it with original table.

Here is the code:

set @rank:=0;

select myScore.Score, myRank.Rank

from (select Score from Scores order by Score desc) as myScore, (select Score, @rank:=@rank+1 as Rank from Scores group by Score order by Score desc) as myRank

where myScore.Score = myRank.Score

**Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        DENSE_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC) `Rank`
FROM Scores

**Not Dense Rank:**

SELECT Score,
        (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT b.Score)+1 FROM Scores b WHERE b.Score > Scores.Score) as `Rank`
FROM Scores
Order by 1 desc;

Subquery shows number of score that's larger than the score in the original table. So the max one has 0 score larger than itself. '+1' to get the rank as '1'. This is similar to question 185:)
Rank is a keyword so use  \'Rank\' with single quotes while giving column name

[@ishtiaq755](/ishtiaq755) That\'s not what OP is talking about. They are talking about labeling your column name as "rank". If you don\'t use quotations then it will throw a runtime error for the reason OP listed.
omg, thank you so much
we need to use DENSE_RANK here , because only RANK keyword wont give you consecutive ranking numbers.
Thanks
Thanks mate
Drove me insane before I figured it out
Oh my god! I have been KILLING myself trying to figure out why I was getting runtime errors. This was it!! Thank you!!!

1)
select score,  dense_rank()over( order by score desc) rank from scores

2)
select a.score, count(b.score) as rank
from scores a
 join
(
select distinct score
from scores
) b
on a.score <= b.score
group by a.id, a.score
order by a.score desc

I originally submitted my SQL as:

SELECT
  score AS "Score", dense_rank() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC NULLS LAST) as "Rank"
FROM
  scores
  
  but it said it was wrong, and upon looking at the results it looks like LeetCode added trailing 0's to the "score" column in the output. So instead of "3.76" it would show something like "3.76000000000002" and render my solution incorrect, when it was actually correct. I overrode the bug with the following SQL:
  
  SELECT
  TRUNC(score,2) AS "Score", dense_rank() OVER (ORDER BY score DESC NULLS LAST) as "Rank"
FROM
  scores

Anyone can help?

select score, 
    CASE
        WHEN @pv = score THEN @vrank
        WHEN @pv := score THEN @vrank := @vrank + 1
    END as 'rank'
from scores, (select @vrank := 0, @pv := NULL) r
order by score desc

this one gives correct answer just like below

Did anyone solve it the same way as me?

# DO NOT USE (PARTITION BY)

select score, dense_rank() over (order by score desc) as 'rank'
from scores

select score, 
 dense_rank() over (order by score desc) as rank 
 from scores 
 order by score desc;
Please find solution below\n`select score, dense_rank() over(order by score desc) as \'rank\' from scores`
Just wondering if window function is acceptable in an interview.

Took some help from other posts -

select score, dense_rank() over (order by score desc) as 'rank'
from Scores

with rank as (
select score, rank() over (order by score desc) as rank
from(
    select distinct score
    from Scores
) a
)

select a.score , b.rank 
from Scores a
join rank b
on a.score = b.score

# MYSQL Solution 
**select score,  Dense_RANK() OVER( order by score desc ) as 'Rank' from Scores order by score desc;**


o/p

Runtime: 224 ms, faster than 83.93% of MySQL online submissions for Rank Scores.
Memory Usage: 0B, less than 100.00% of MySQL online submissions for Rank Scores.
\nselect score,dense_rank() over(order by score desc) as \'Rank\' from scores;

if you don't want a simple solution, here it is.

select s1.Score, s3.Rank from scores s1
join (select s2.Score, rank() over (order by s2.Score desc) 'Rank' from scores s2
group by Score order by 'Rank' desc) s3 on s1.Score = s3.Score
order by s1.Score desc
**ACCEPTED SOLUTION USING DENSE_RANK( ) FUNCTION OF MYSQL**\nSELECT Score, DENSE_RANK() over(order by Score desc) \'Rank\' from Scores order by \'Rank\' asc;

'''
select s1.score, (select count(distinct s2.score) from scores s2 where s1.score<=s2.score) 'Rank' 
from scores s1
order by s1.score desc

'''

with cte as (Select s1.score, ifnull(count(s2.score)+1,1) as rn
from
(Select distinct score
from scores) as s1
left join
(select distinct score
from scores) as s2
on s1.score < s2.score
group by s1.score)

Select s.score, cte.rn as 'Rank'
from scores s
join cte
on s.score = cte.score
order by rn

'''
with ref_table as 
(select distinct Score, row_number() over (order by Score desc) as rankk
from Scores
group by Score)

select a.Score, b.rankk
from Scores a left join ref_table b on a.score=b.score
order by a.Score desc
'''
This is my solution, but it is not accepted because it is wants 4.00000 instead of 4.00 for MS Sql Server.
Don't know why?

The following is accepted as Oracle and MS Server but failed if MySQL is selected. DENSE_RANK is valid under MySQL.

select Score, dense_rank() OVER(ORDER BY Score desc) AS Rank
FROM Scores

title: First Bad Version
question_content:
You are a product manager and currently leading a team to develop a new product. Unfortunately, the latest version of your product fails the quality check. Since each version is developed based on the previous version, all the versions after a bad version are also bad.

Suppose you have n versions [1, 2, ..., n] and you want to find out the first bad one, which causes all the following ones to be bad.

You are given an API bool isBadVersion(version) which returns whether version is bad. Implement a function to find the first bad version. You should minimize the number of calls to the API.

 

Example 1:

Input: n = 5, bad = 4
Output: 4
Explanation:
call isBadVersion(3) -> false
call isBadVersion(5) -> true
call isBadVersion(4) -> true
Then 4 is the first bad version.

Example 2:

Input: n = 1, bad = 1
Output: 1

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= bad <= n <= 231 - 1

solutions.title: a-good-warning-to-me-to-use-start-end-start-2-to-avoid-overflow
o-lgn-simple-java-solution
python-simple-2-lines-solution

python-solution-easy-to-understand-binary-search-with-detailed-explanation
solutions.content:
### Solution
```
def firstBadVersion(self, n):
        i = 1
        j = n
        while (i < j):
            pivot = (i+j) // 2
            if (isBadVersion(pivot)):
                j = pivot       # keep track of the leftmost bad version
            else:
                i = pivot + 1   # the one after the rightmost good version
        return i
```

### Remarks
* We use` i = 1` instead of `0` as base case because there's no index operation involved and the product version starts from 1.
* We use `j` to keep track of the leftmost bad version we have checked, so that any version after` j `would not be the first bad version we want.
* We use `i `to keep track of the leftmost unknown version which has a good version before it, so that any version before` i` would be a good version.
* Therefore, `i` would move towards `j` step by step and stop when it becomes the first bad version.

****Please upvote if you find this post useful, and welcome to any further discussion!***

clear-concept-tle-overflow-mechanism-what-s-wrong-with-left-right-2
solutions.content:
The only **trap** in this question is regarding *integer overflow.*
Let's grab the underlying **OVERFLOW CONCEPT.**
Integer range in most of programming languages like C++, Java is **-2147483648 to 2147483647**.

For all those who used ```int mid = (left + right)/2;``` 
When you check the reason of TLE, it says one of following test case: *2126753390  1702766719*
The values for *left, right, and mid* in the subsequent iterations are:

	left = 1             right = 2126753390,  mid = 1063376695
	left = 1063376696    right = 2126753390,  mid = -552418605
	left = -552418604    right = 2126753390,  mid = 787167393
	left = 787167394     right = 2126753390,  mid = -690523256
	.
	.
	and so on...

### REASON OF TLE :
The value of **mid** switches between positive and negative signs. **This will never stop, resulting in an infinite loop and hence TLE.**

### WHY it behaves this way?
In the second iteration, mathematically it should be
```(1063376696 + 2126753390) /2 = (3190130086) /2   = 1595065043```
but but due to *overflows of the integer range*, it will be interpreted as
```(1063376696 + 2126753390) / 2 = (-1104837210) / 2   = -552418605```

Let's understand it in a more intuitive way, by taking easier example:
Que: **How can we store value 10 in a data structure which can hold values in range [-4,3] ?**
It will overflow and handled by complier by its **overflow and underflow mechanism.**
The following section describes its inner working.
# OVERFLOW MECHANISM :
The range is specified as -4 to 3. If given num falls in this range, it will be stored as it is. 
Otherwise it will start filling in cyclic manner from opposite end. 
For e.g., 
-12, 4, 12 will be represented as -4,
-14, -6, 10 will be represented as 2, etc.
( Ans:- num=10, lower=-4, upper=3. Hence, representational value = 2 )

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/4d0e04b5-4879-4d5e-9e97-38094eb10bcb_1662454758.777058.png)

(Above diagram shows 3-bit signed representation of a number)

This value can be calculated by recursive calls as follows: [RECURSIVE APPROACH]
```
 public static long dataType(long num, long lower, long upper){
        long range = upper-lower+1;
        if(num > upper)              // num is greater than upper, so we substract the range
            return dataType(num - range, lower, upper);
        if(num < lower)              // num is lesser than lower, so we add the range
            return dataType(num + range, lower, upper);
			
		// num lies between lower and upper, so we return it
		return num;          
    }
```
However, recursive calls may fill up memory. Using modular arithmetic, we can solve this in O(1) constant time.
Similar function as below is called, each time you do TYPE CASTING - NARROWING.

### Working of Type Casting (narrowing) :
```
public static long dataType(long num, long lower, long upper){
        if(lower<=num && num<=upper)
            return num;                  // if num lies between lower and upper, we return it
            
        long range = upper-lower+1;     // size of window in which num can be stored
        long value = num % range;       // to bring the num in the range
        if(num > upper){
            if(value > upper) value -= range;  //if value exceeds, bring it back in range
        }
        if(num < lower){
            if(value < lower) value += range; //if value preceeds, bring it back in range
        }
        return value;  // the representational value of the num
    }
```

Now, you can create your custom range data type with different lower and upper bounds and have fun :)
like lower=69, upper=96, num=116 hehe!

Voila, we have made an exellent *DISCOVERY !!*
**The data types in java, c++ etc. are nothing but an *special case* of our program.**
Any num can be taken and change in values of lower and upper given:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/8b365166-8a41-4310-902f-835adb7a4d60_1662460446.4986744.png)

### FLAW in behaviour of mid :
*After an overflow, the compiler starts again from the least limit of value (i.e. -2147483648 in integer case) and adds the remaining surplus value.*
*[ num=3190130086, lower=-2147483648, upper=2147483647 ]*

Here, 3190130086 - 2147483648 - 2147483648 = -1104837210. 
The limit has crossed twice here, followed by a division giving -552418605

**Understand it like, you need to give someone 4.5 litre of water but you have only bottle of 1 litre. What will you do?
You will reuse(or recycle) the bottle 4 times, then last time you give 500mL as per mark. *Compiler works the same way!***

### isBadVersion( ) API working :
For those who think, this is implemented using arrays, and accessing **-ve** value value from array will give *Runtime Error*(IndexOutOfBound)
Its not! **The inner working of API** is similar as follows, where *firstBadIndex* is passed by different method. 
```
bool isBadVersion(int value, int firstBadIndex){
        if(value < firstBadIndex) return false;
        else return true;
    }
```

#### HOW TO FIX?
To solve this anomaly, an equivalent mathematical formula, which is,
```int mid = left + (right-left)/2;``` is used,

```
RHS = left + (right-left)/2
    = left + right/2 - left/2
	= left/2 + right/2
    = (left + right)/2
```
This equivalent formula ensures that `(right-left)/2` lies between the bounds of integer range and does not overflows.
Keep this formula in mind, as it also performs better in sorting techniques like quick sort and others.

Alternatively, to avoid overflow, one can also use higher range limit data types like **long**. But then you will miss this beauty behind the code. 
**Don't waste unnecessary space by taking higher data range (some people make a habit to do so) instead, understand the underlying concept.**
Make program less space complex and yourself a better programmer. ; )
#keepGrinding #happyCoding

solutions.title: simple-python-solution-using-binary-search
solutions.content:
**🔼 IF YOU FIND THIS POST HELPFUL PLEASE UPVOTE 👍**

Visit this blog to learn Python tips and techniques and to find a Leetcode solution with an explanation: https://www.python-techs.com/

**Solution:**
```
class Solution:
    def firstBadVersion(self, n: int) -> int:
        left = 1
        right = n
        result = 1
        
        while left<=right:
            mid = (left+right)//2
            if isBadVersion(mid) == False:
                left = mid+1
            else:
                right = mid-1
                result = mid
                
        return result
```
**Thank you for reading! 😄 Comment if you have any questions or feedback.**

<!-- # Intuition -->
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

<!-- # Approach -->
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:$$O(log n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:$$O(1)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
// The API isBadVersion is defined for you.
// bool isBadVersion(int version);

class Solution {
public:
    int firstBadVersion(int n) {
        long long int start = 0 ; 
        long long int end = n ; 
        long long int minBadVersion ;
         
        while (start <= end)
        {
            long long int mid = (start + end) / 2 ; 

            if (isBadVersion(mid) == 1)
            {
                minBadVersion = mid ; 
                end = mid - 1 ; 
            }
            else
            {
                start = mid + 1 ; 
            }
        }
        return minBadVersion ;
    }
};
```
![815a317f-9cdf-46e2-a397-af8869dafa2e_1673498197.3721023.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/65eeb207-f2a9-4d1b-9d13-2c8573d657ed_1677603105.5077243.png)

solutions.title: 278-solution-with-step-by-step-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
In this solution, we maintain two pointers left and right that represent the range of versions we are searching. We start with left = 1 and right = n. At each iteration of the while loop, we compute the midpoint mid of the range as (left + right) // 2, and we call the isBadVersion API to check whether version mid is bad or not.

If isBadVersion(mid) returns True, then we know that the first bad version must be in the range [left, mid], so we update right = mid. Otherwise, the first bad version must be in the range [mid+1, right], so we update left = mid + 1. We continue this process until left and right converge to a single version, which must be the first bad version.

This algorithm runs in logarithmic time and makes only O(1) calls to the isBadVersion API at each iteration, which minimizes the total number of calls to the API.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def firstBadVersion(self, n: int) -> int:
        left, right = 1, n
        while left < right:
            mid = left + (right - left) // 2
            if isBadVersion(mid):
                right = mid
            else:
                left = mid + 1
        return left

```

solutions.content:
The solution is quite simple and elegant. Since we know the version numbers are distinct and are in ascending order, we can simply use binary search to search for the first bad version.

Steps:
1. Start with how every binary search starts. With two pointers, one at the first element of the array and one at the last.
	```
	low, high = 1, n
	```
2. Run a while loop as long as low is less than high. (The reason to check ```low < high ```  will be explained below)
	```
	while low < high: mid = (low + high) // 2
	```
3. Next check if the low pointer is not a bad version then set ```low = mid + 1``` else ```high = mid ```. 


The reason to set `low = mid + 1` and `high = mid` and not `high = mid - 1`. Since the bad version is the second part of the array we can't remove all the bad versions from the binary search since we have to return the recent bad version not the most stable version. The is the exact reason why we don't check for low <= high in the while loop since it can cause an infinite loop. You can return both low and high since they will be both equal at the end of the binary search. 

Solution:
```
low, high = 1, n
while low < high:
	mid = (low + high) // 2
	if not isBadVersion(mid):
		low = mid + 1
	else:
		high = mid 
return high
```

solutions.content:
<hr/>

### Approach:
1. Find the `mid` element from 1 to `n`
2. Check if `mid` is bad or not
3. If mid is bad, store it in variable and go to left part of array, because we need to find first bad version. **(end = mid-1)**
4. If number is not bad, go to right part of an array. **(start=mid+1)**
<hr/>

### Code:
<hr/>

```
class Solution {
public:
    int firstBadVersion(int n) {
        int s = 0;
        int e = n;
        int bad;
        while(s<=e){
            
            int mid = s + (e-s)/2;
            
            if(isBadVersion(mid)){
                bad = mid;
                e = mid-1;
            }
            else
                s = mid+1;
            
        }
        return bad;
    }
};
```

solutions.content:
## ***Please Upvote my solution, if you find it helpful ;)***

# Intuition
The problem requires finding the first bad version in a given range of versions. A bad version indicates that all subsequent versions are also bad. We need to optimize the solution to minimize the number of calls to the isBadVersion() API.

# Approach
1. Initially, we have the range of versions from 1 to n, where n is the total number of versions.
1. We want to find the first bad version, which indicates that all subsequent versions are also bad.
1. To optimize our search, we use a binary search algorithm.
1. We start with the middle version and check if it is a bad version.
1. If it is a bad version, we can conclude that all versions after it are also bad.
1. If it is not a bad version, we can conclude that all versions before it are good.
1. Based on this information, we update our search range accordingly.
1. If the middle version is bad, we search in the left half (lower versions).
1. If the middle version is good, we search in the right half (higher versions).
1. We repeat steps 4 and 5 until we narrow down the search range to a single version.
1. At this point, we have found the first bad version.
1. Finally, we return the index of the first bad version.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
The time complexity of the binary search algorithm is $$O(log n)$$, where n is the number of versions. This is because we divide the range of versions in half at each step of the binary search, reducing the search space exponentially.

- Space complexity:
The space complexity is $$O(1)$$ since the solution uses only a constant amount of additional space to store the variables start, end, and mid.

# Code
```
/* The isBadVersion API is defined in the parent class VersionControl.
      boolean isBadVersion(int version); */

public class Solution extends VersionControl {
    public int firstBadVersion(int n) {

        int start = 1; // Start of the search range
        int end = n; // End of the search range
        int mid = 0; // Variable to store the middle version
        
        while (start <= end) {
            mid = start + (end - start) / 2; // Calculate the middle version

            if (isBadVersion(mid)) {
                end = mid - 1; // Adjust the end to search in the left half (lower versions)
            } else {
                // If the middle version is not bad, all versions before it are good
                start = mid + 1; // Adjust the start to search in the right half (higher versions)
            }
        }

        return end + 1; // Return the index of the first bad version
    }
}

```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
To find the first bad version, we need to perform a search. However, we don't want to search all the versions one by one because that would take a long time. Instead, we can use the binary search algorithm to search for the first bad version in a more efficient way.
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Our approach will be to use binary search to search for the first bad version. We will start by initializing two pointers, left and right, to 1 and n, respectively. We will then find the middle version by computing the average of left and right, and call isBadVersion on the middle version. If it returns True, then we know that the first bad version is either the middle version or a version before it. So we will move the right pointer to the middle version. If it returns False, then we know that the first bad version is either the middle version or a version after it. So we will move the left pointer to the middle version + 1. We will repeat this process until left and right converge to the first bad version.
# Complexity
- Time complexity:$$O(log n)$$, where $$ n$$ is the number of versions.
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$, because we are only using constant extra space.
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
# The isBadVersion API is already defined for you.
# def isBadVersion(version: int) -> bool:

class Solution:
    def firstBadVersion(self, n: int) -> int:
        left = 1
        right = n
        while left < right:
            mid = left + (right - left) // 2
            if isBadVersion(mid):
                right = mid
            else:
                left = mid + 1
        return left
```

solutions.content:
Hi Everyone, 

In this solution, we will move from ***Brute Force Solution Approach to Optimal Solution Approach***.

In Optimal Solution, we will see a ***beautiful application of Binary Search***.

**Brute Force Approach**

We will do a simple scan from 1 till n and as soon as we find the first number which is a bad version, we return it. 

* ***Time Complexity - O(N)***
* ***Space Complexity - O(1)***
     
**Optimal Approach**

Since we know that 1 to n is going to behave like a sorted array, let us fix our left to 1 and right to n. (Imagine 1,2,3,4.....n)

**Applying Binary Search, suppose we have a mid and at this mid, our function says it is a good version**. 

* It means that the required first bad version will definitely lie towards right hand side, so do left = mid + 1.

* Again, if the function says this mid is a bad version, then our answer can be this mid or somewhere before this. To check, we can check if (mid-1) is a good version or bad. If it is a good version, mid will be our answer. If it is a bad version, we will do right = mid - 1 as answer will definitely be before mid.

* To handle edge cases, conditions are added below (when mid == 1)

***Points to note*** : 
***The given function returns True for a value, it means the version is bad.***
***mid = left + (right - left)// 2 is done to avoid integer overflow issues.***


* ***Time Complexity - O(log(N))***
* ***Space Complexity - O(1)***
        
Here is the code for Brute Force Approach - 
```
	for i in range(1, n+1):
		if isBadVersion(i) == True:
			return i
```

Here is the code for Optimal Approach - 
     
   ```
		left = 1
        right = n
        while left <= right:
            
            mid = left + (right - left) // 2
            
            if isBadVersion(mid) == False: #== if a version is not bad, answer will definitely lie after m
                left = mid + 1 
                
            else: #== if a version is bad 
			
                #we will check (m-1)th number - if it is bad, we will do right = m - 1
                #if it is good, we will return answer
                if mid == 1:
                    return mid
					
                if isBadVersion(mid-1):
                    right = mid - 1
					
                else:
                    return mid
                
```
         

     
#Time Complexity - O(log(N)) and Space Complexity - O(1)

# Intuition
Use Binary seach to solve the problem

# Approach
Find whether the mid version is BadVersion or not, using Binary search, reduce the n versions to halves until the source of bad version found.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(log n)$$

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$

# Code
```
# The isBadVersion API is already defined for you.
# def isBadVersion(version: int) -> bool:

class Solution:
    def firstBadVersion(self, n: int) -> int:
        if n==1 and isBadVersion(n):
            return 1
        l = 1
        r = n

        while l <= r:
            mid = l + (r-l) // 2
            if isBadVersion(mid):
                if isBadVersion(mid -1) == False:
                    return mid
                else:
                    r = mid-1
            else:
               l = mid + 1 
            
        return 0

```

# Approach
- We will initialize two pointers left and right to 0, n respectively. 

- We will perfrom binary Search in order to find first bad version. 

- First we will check that if `isBadVersion(mid)` is True or not. If its True then version before mid will also be bad so we will set right pointer to mid and will search in left half.

- If `isBadVersion(mid)` is not True then we will set left pointer to `mid+1` and will search in right half. Search will continue till left < right and at the end we will return left `l`

- This Solution has Time Complexity of `O(log n)` as we are using binary search and Space Complexity of `O(1)` as we are using constant memory space. 

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def firstBadVersion(self, n: int) -> int:
        l, r = 0, n 
        while l < r:
            mid = (l+r) // 2
            if isBadVersion(mid): r = mid
            else: l = mid+1
        return l
```
